content.text: Bash rm Command - Remove Files or Directories
Using the rm Command
The rm command is used to remove files or directories.
content.html: The rm command is used to remove files or directories.

content.text: Be careful, as removed files cannot be easily recovered.
content.html: Be careful, as removed files cannot be easily recovered.

content.text: Basic Usage
To remove a file, use rm filename :
content.html: To remove a file, use rm filename:

content.code_html: rm my_file.txt

content.text: Options
The rm command has options to change how it works:
content.html: The rm command has options to change how it works:

content.text: -v Option: Verbose Mode
The -v option enables verbose mode, which displays the files being removed in the terminal.
content.html: The -v option enables verbose mode, which displays the files being removed in the terminal.

content.text: This is useful for tracking the removal process, especially when dealing with many files.
content.html: This is useful for tracking the removal process, especially when dealing with many files.

content.code_html:
rm -v my_new_file.txt
removed 'my_new_file.txt'

content.text: Remove Directories Recursively
The -r option allows you to delete directories and all their contents.
content.html: The -r option allows you to delete directories and all their contents.

content.code_html: rm -r directory

content.text: Prompt Before Removal
The -i option will prompt you before each file is deleted, helping you avoid accidental deletions.
content.html: The -i option will prompt you before each file is deleted, helping you avoid accidental deletions.

content.code:
rm
-i my_file.txt
rm: remove regular file 'my_file.txt'?
content.code_html:
rm -i my_file.txt
rm: remove regular file 'my_file.txt'?

content.text: Force Removal
The -f option forces deletion without any prompts.
content.html: The -f option forces deletion without any prompts.

content.code_html: rm -f file.txt

content.text: Using rm Safely
Always double-check the files and directories you are about to delete, especially when using the -r and -f options.
content.html: Always double-check the files and directories you are about to delete, especially when using the -r and -f options.

content.code:
rm
-i -r images
rm: descend into directory 'images'?
content.code_html:
rm -i -r images
rm: descend into directory 'images'?
